comments.body: @dmsimard To make this more like ec2_instance I was going to consolidate `db_security_groups` and `vpc_security_group_ids` into one `security_groups` option (retaining the original option names as aliases), but decided not to since I don't have access to an EC2-Classic account and cannot test the edge cases.

Yeah I think it's fair to keep the module consistent with the API (despite being inconsistent with other AWS modules, it's not technically out fault) for the sake of keeping things maintainable. It's a shame from a UX perspective though.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +141,145 @@          - The name of the DB parameter group to associate with this DB instance. When creating the DB instance if this
            argument is omitted the default DBParameterGroup for the specified engine is used.
    db_security_groups:
        description:
          - (EC2-Classic platform) A list of DB security groups to associate with this DB instance.

comments.body: it doesn't look like there's an accompanying wait_timeout option. Can we add to the docs what the max time the module will wait, or if it can hang indefinitely if RDS hangs?
I added to the docs and made the made the possible wait time less ridiculously long than I had it.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +62,66 @@            be set to 'instance' or not provided. C(source_db_instance_identifier) must be provided with this option.
        type: bool
    wait:
        description:
          - Whether to wait for the cluster to be available, stopped, or deleted. At a later time a wait_timeout option may be added.

comments.body: Is there somewhere in boto3 we can pull this out from? It would be great to not have to update this if Amazon adds more engine options.

I could pull it from https://github.com/boto/botocore/blob/c632931a6cc5eab4113c976d430bcb9c059f829f/botocore/data/rds/2014-09-01/service-2.json#L3045? It doesn't look like boto3 or botocore ever validate or do anything to the engine other than specify it to be a string. They just pass along the value. We could do that too. But then the user won't know what the valid values are without looking it up. I would be okay with removing `choices` from this option in the argspec (I'd have to move the documented choices to the description) and add the list as accepted (last known and in need of occassional-updating) enginges to the error message in case it is a bad value. That wouldn't impede unattended growth. Sound okay?
Yeah, maybe you could add to the documentation on the option the current engines, but remove the `choices` validation so that new engines will still work but may be undocumented for up to 1 release.
Addressed, also added a helpful error for invalid engines

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +176,180 @@    engine:
        description:
          - The name of the database engine to be used for this DB instance. This is required to create an instance.
            Valid choices are aurora | aurora-mysql | aurora-postgresql | mariadb | mysql | oracle-ee | oracle-se |
            oracle-se1 | oracle-se2 | postgres | sqlserver-ee | sqlserver-ex | sqlserver-se | sqlserver-web

comments.body: I'm thinking this would be a good one to set a `boto3_at_least` of 1.5.0, which looks like when the TDE options were added. It was also released about one year ago, so would match with the boto3 support policy we'd had in mind.
